defs.docs: Futures, streams, and async I/O combinators.

attributes.value: / Futures, streams, and async I/O combinators.
/ This crate is a subset of [futures] that compiles an order of magnitude faster, fixes minor
/ warts in its API, fills in some obvious gaps, and removes almost all unsafe code from it.
/ In short, this crate aims to be more enjoyable than [futures] but still fully compatible with

defs.name: yield_now
defs.docs: Wakes the current task and returns [`Poll::Pending`] once.

attributes.value: / Wakes the current task and returns [`Poll::Pending`] once.
/ This function is useful when we want to cooperatively give time to the task scheduler. It is
/ generally a good idea to yield inside loops because that way we make sure long-running tasks
/ don't prevent other tasks from running.

defs.name: race
defs.value:
pub fn race<T, F1, F2>(F1, F2) -> Race<F1, F2> where F1: Future<Output = T>,
F2: Future<Output = T>
defs.docs: Returns the result of the future that completes first, with no preference if both are ready.

attributes.value: / Returns the result of the future that completes first, with no preference if both are ready.
/ Each time [`Race`] is polled, the two inner futures are polled in random order. Therefore, no
/ future takes precedence over the other if both can complete at the same time.
/ If you have preference for one of the futures, use the [`or()`] function or the
/ // One of the two futures is randomly chosen as the winner.

defs.name: fold
defs.value:
pub fn fold<T, F>(Self, T, F) -> FoldFuture<Self, F, T> where Self: Sized,
F: FnMut(T, Self::Item) -> T
defs.docs: Accumulates a computation over the stream.

attributes.value: / Accumulates a computation over the stream.
/ The computation begins with the accumulator value set to `init`, and then applies `f` to
/ the accumulator and each item in the stream. The final accumulator value is returned.
/ let sum = s.fold(0, |acc, x| acc + x).await;

defs.value:
pub fn try_fold<T, E, F, B>(&mut Self, B, F) -> TryFoldFuture<, Self, F, B>
where Self: Stream<Item = Result<T, E>> + Unpin + Sized, F: FnMut(B, T) ->
Result<B, E>
defs.docs: Accumulates a fallible computation over the stream.

attributes.value: / Accumulates a fallible computation over the stream.
/ The computation begins with the accumulator value set to `init`, and then applies `f` to
/ the accumulator and each item in the stream. The final accumulator value is returned, or an
/ let mut s = stream::iter(vec![Ok(1), Ok(2), Ok(3)]);

defs.name: scan
defs.value:
pub fn scan<St, B, F>(Self, St, F) -> Scan<Self, St, F> where Self: Sized,
F: FnMut(&mut St, Self::Item) -> Option<B>
defs.docs: Maps items of the stream to new values using a state value and a closure.

attributes.value: / Maps items of the stream to new values using a state value and a closure.
/ Scanning begins with the inital state set to `initial_state`, and then applies `f` to the
/ state and each item in the stream. The stream stops when `f` returns `None`.

W: AsyncWrite + Unpin
defs.docs: Copies the entire contents of a reader into a writer.

attributes.value: / Copies the entire contents of a reader into a writer.
/ This function will read data from `reader` and write it into `writer` in a streaming fashion
/ On success, returns the total number of bytes copied.

defs.name: BlockOn
defs.docs: Blocks on all async I/O operations and implements [`std::io`] traits.

attributes.value: / Blocks on all async I/O operations and implements [`std::io`] traits.
/ Sometimes async I/O needs to be used in a blocking manner. If calling [`future::block_on()`]
/ manually all the time becomes too tedious, use this type for more convenient blocking on async
/ [`Seek`][`std::io::Seek`] if the inner type implements [`AsyncRead`], [`AsyncWrite`], or
/ If writing data through the [`Write`][`std::io::Write`] trait, make sure to flush before
/ dropping the [`BlockOn`] handle or some buffered data might get lost.
/ // This line blocks - note that there is no await:

defs.name: read_until
defs.value:
pub fn read_until<'a>(&'a mut Self, u8, &'a mut Vec<u8>)
-> ReadUntilFuture<, Self> where Self: Unpin
defs.docs: Reads all bytes and appends them into `buf` until the delimiter `byte` or EOF is found.

attributes.value: / Reads all bytes and appends them into `buf` until the delimiter `byte` or EOF is found.
/ This method will read bytes from the underlying stream until the delimiter or EOF is
/ found. All bytes up to and including the delimiter (if found) will be appended to `buf`.
/ If successful, returns the total number of bytes read.

where Self: Unpin

attributes.value: / Reads all bytes and appends them into `buf` until a newline (the 0xA byte) or EOF is found.
/ This method will read bytes from the underlying stream until the newline delimiter (the
/ 0xA byte) or EOF is found. All bytes up to, and including, the newline delimiter (if found)
/ If successful, returns the total number of bytes read.

defs.name: AsyncReadExt
defs.docs: Extension trait for [`AsyncRead`].

defs.name: read
defs.value: pub fn read<'a>(&'a mut Self, &'a mut [u8]) -> ReadFuture where Self: Unpin
defs.docs: Reads some bytes from the byte stream.

attributes.value: / Reads some bytes from the byte stream.
/ On success, returns the total number of bytes read.
/ If the return value is `Ok(n)`, then it must be guaranteed that
/ `0 <= n <= buf.len()`. A nonzero `n` value indicates that the buffer has been
/ filled with `n` bytes of data. If `n` is `0`, then it can indicate one of two
/ 1. This reader has reached its "end of file" and will likely no longer be able to
/    produce bytes. Note that this does not mean that the reader will always no
/    longer be able to produce bytes.
/ 2. The buffer specified was 0 bytes in length.

attributes.value: / Like [`read()`][`AsyncReadExt::read()`], except it reads into a slice of buffers.
/ Data is copied to fill each buffer in order, with the final buffer possibly being
/ only partially filled. This method must behave same as a single call to

defs.name: write
defs.value: pub fn write<'a>(&'a mut Self, &'a [u8]) -> WriteFuture where Self: Unpin
defs.docs: Writes some bytes into the byte stream.

attributes.value: / Writes some bytes into the byte stream.
/ Returns the number of bytes written from the start of the buffer.
/ If the return value is `Ok(n)` then it must be guaranteed that
/ `0 <= n <= buf.len()`. A return value of `0` typically means that the underlying
/ object is no longer able to accept bytes and will likely not be able to in the
/ future as well, or that the provided buffer is empty.

defs.name: write_all
defs.value:
pub fn write_all<'a>(&'a mut Self, &'a [u8]) -> WriteAllFuture where
Self: Unpin
defs.docs: Writes an entire buffer into the byte stream.

attributes.value: / Writes an entire buffer into the byte stream.
/ This method will keep calling [`write()`][`AsyncWriteExt::write()`] until there is no more
/ data to be written or an error occurs. It will not return before the entire buffer is
/ successfully written or an error occurs.

defs.name: split
defs.value:
pub fn split<T>(T) -> (ReadHalf<T>, WriteHalf<T>) where T: AsyncRead +
AsyncWrite + Unpin
defs.docs: Splits a stream into [`AsyncRead`] and [`AsyncWrite`] halves.

attributes.value: / Splits a stream into [`AsyncRead`] and [`AsyncWrite`] halves.

defs.name: ReadHalf
defs.docs: The read half returned by [`split()`].
